steps.title: Magnitude of the problem
steps.description:
I've talked to many people who had allergies. Some take bi-weekly shots, some take pills, some vacuum the house every day to lessen the symptoms.

Before we put this condition behind us, let me quickly ask you:

How much time a week would you say you spend dealing with this problem?

Including trips to the doctor's office, pharmacy, vacuuming the house, etc

answers.text: Less than an hour per week

steps.title: Magnitude of the problem
steps.description:
${echo}

And how much money do you spend each month on this problem?

steps.title: Life after the cure

answers.text: It will change my life immensely

steps.title: Let's begin
steps.description:
${echo}

Great. And with that, let's begin!

steps.title: Pronouns
steps.description: What pronouns do you use?

steps.title: Your immune system
steps.description:
The role of your immune system is to keep you alive and well, and for the most part, it’s doing its job rather well.

However …

Even immune systems make mistakes sometimes. Nobody’s perfect right?

An allergy is usually a mistake caused by a false neurological association. 

Like “crossing the wires” in your mind.

 I’ve worked with many people who have successfully acquired different allergies in very creative ways.

The good thing is that we can retrain your immune system to once again respond to cats in an appropriate ways.

steps.title: Retraining the immune system
steps.description:
What we are about to do is gently retrain your immune system.

Correct the mistake it did when it learned to give you these “warning signals” packaged in an allergic response.

Notice the key-word here:

Gently.

When we’re done, your immune system will accurately identify cats for what they are. Harmless (some would say adorable) furry creatures.

This will have some side benefits of course

steps.title: Stronger immune system - One less frontier
steps.description:
Up until today, cats were one more thing your immune system was on the lookout for. That’s another frontier to manage.

Each one of these frontiers consumes resources of course. Resources you are about to allocate to more constructive functions.

Like we said, for the most part,  it’s good to enforce these frontiers because it keeps us safe from unwanted infiltrators.

But now that we are going to re-identify cats for what they are, we are going to have one less frontier to worry about, which will result in...

answers.text: Oh damn the suspense is killing me!

steps.title: Less stress on the body
steps.description:
By closing that frontier, we'll have reduced the maintenance requirements for “being you.”

There are countless benefits for reducing stress on the system, and now you’ll have more resources to allocate to different such as:

- Fighting real dangers (viruses, infections, etc)
 - Digestion
- Sleep

And many more.

You’ll also be actually safer without that dangerous old allergic response you used to have!

steps.title: Missing allergies
steps.description: You probably had this response for quite some time now in the past, so before we proceed I need to ask you something very important, which might seem a bit strange.

answers.text: Oh you got me curious now Adam!

steps.title: Would you miss it?
steps.description:
After we’re done with this process, the allergic response you used to have will be gone. 

Sometimes it happens instantaneously, and sometimes it takes a few days, but it will be gone.

I know you’ll probably say you won't miss it, but I must ask because, well, these are the rules ;) And also, I’m very thorough like that.

So, imagine we are a few days into the future, and you, my friend, are 100% healthy around cats.

There’s nothing left of that part of you which used to cause the old allergic response.

would you miss it in any way?

Is there any part of you who objects to keep being free of this old condition, and enjoy being around cats if you wish?

Again, I know it’s a bit strange to ask, but I like to be sure before we continue.

answers.text: 100% healthy around cats? I’m loving it!

steps.title: Will you miss it?
Controlled response
steps.description:
In a minute I’ll ask you to get back just a *little bit* of the allergic response you had in the past.

We’re doing this in order to get some reference to the very near future, in which this response will be already gone completely from your life.

Don’t do it before I tell you.

I’ll want you to go back to the past, to the first time you had the allergic response, and relive that moment slowly. As you do so, the moment you start feeling the allergic response back, “wake up” and “shake it off”

By “wake up” I mean reorient yourself back to the present moment, here with me, stand up and walk around for a few seconds.

### Let me outline the steps for you:

1. Go back to the past, to the first experience in which you had the allergic response
2. Relive that experience slowly
3. As soon as you start feeling that allergic response in your body, “wake up” and “shake it off” by standing up, and walk around for a few seconds.

Some people like to do steps 1-2 with eyes closed. It’s your mind, your body, and your decision of course.

Ready?

Do it now and let me know when you’re done by scrolling down the page.

…



…



…



…



…



…


Back?

Great. Were you able to generate some of the allergic response from the past?

**No**

OK, sometimes it takes a bit more effort to conjure up this response from the past. So here are two things to try next: 

Relive that memory again, and this time pay extra attention to the bodily sensations of that experience.


Relive the strongest past experience you have with the past allergic response

Also, if you touched any cats in any of those experiences, pay extra attention to the texture and temperature of these furry creatures.

Do it now, and let me know when you’re done.

…


…


…


…


…


…

Well? How was it? Were you able to generate some of the response now?

**No**

OK, here’s the next alternative to try. 

Imagine playing with 4 cats right now. Really feel their touch in your hand, and in your face. Imagine rubbing your face or your cheeks on their fur. 

Don’t hold back, really get in there.

Do this for up to 3 minutes. 

Remember, as soon as you start feeling the allergic response, “wake up” and walk around a bit.

Do it now and let me know when you’re done.


…


…



…



…


Back?

Great.

Were you able to generate now any of the allergic response?

**No**

OK, this requires some investigation, so let's have a quick chat before you continue.

I'm mostly available on my personal WhatsApp:

+972506867607

Or at facebook messenger:

https://m.me/shlakyshlaky

You can also send me an email at:

goldy@adamgoldman.me

**Yes**

Great.

(If you didn’t get up and walked around a bit, please do it now before continuing)

Now before we move to the next step, there’s another reason I asked you to generate some of the old allergic response.

Not telling you makes the effect stronger, but it’s no biggie if you already know.

steps.title: A sneaky little trick
steps.description:
By generating the allergic response in your mind alone, i.e. without physically being exposed to the stimulant, you just provided an unshakeable proof to your entire system that, well, this is not a “purely physical” condition.

If this was 100% physical, you wouldn’t have been able to do so.

Pretty cool eh?
steps.notes: We can talk further about the “mind-body” split after this process if you wish

steps.title: A similar stimulant
steps.description:
OK this next step is very simple.

Think of something that is very similar to a cat, in which you already respond appropriately to. Most people go for a dog, but if something else comes to your mind, by all means, go for it.

steps.title: Anchoring preface
steps.description:
${echo}

Great.

Now choose a place on your body you can comfortably press for a few minutes.

These usually work well:

- Pressing two fingers together
- Pressing the index and middle fingers on your thigh
- Pressing the index and middle fingers on your arm
- Pressing the index and middle fingers on your shoulder

We are going to use that soon to “anchor” a healthy response by your immune system. Don’t worry about the term “anchoring” for now.

Let me know when you’ve found a comfortable spot to press.

(don’t hold on to it yet, just locate the spot)

answers.text: Pressing the index and middle fingers on your thigh
Pressing the index and middle fingers on your arm
Pressing the index and middle fingers on your shoulder

steps.title: Anchoring an appropriate response
steps.description:
Now in a moment, I’ll ask you to imagine touching and playing with the stimulant you chose a couple of steps ago:

${s18}

And really feel the touch on your skin, your hands, body, and even the face.

As you are doing so, start holding the anchor you’ve selected in the previous steps:

#{echo}

After you feel you have “peaked” this experience in your mind, and you really got a good feel of the touch of the similar stimulant:

${s18}

You can let go of the anchor.

Got the steps?

1. Get ready to anchor: ANCHOR
2. Think of the similar stimulant: STIMULANT
3. Imagine touching, playing and rubbing it with your hands, body, and face
4. Start holding the anchor
5. As you really start to sense the touch of the stimulant, release the anchor and reorient yourself here to the present moment.

You can do this with eyes closed or open, whatever is more comfortable for you.

Scroll down when you’re done.

…


…


…


…


…


…


You’re back?

Great!

This resource we just anchored will come in real handy real soon. You’ll see soon enough.

On with the show …

steps.title: The great wall
steps.description:
Now let me ask you a question, my friend.

If you’d have two all-mighty plexiglasses splitting the current room you’re in, into two quarantined spaces, and one plexiglass would be warm, and one would be cold, which one would be a better “isolator”?

Both plexiglasses span across the entire room, cover wall to wall, floor to ceiling. One is cold, one is warm.

Which one do you feel isolates your side of the room from the other side?

If both of them isolates equally strong, just pick one.

steps.title: The great wall
steps.description:
${echo}

Great, so imagine that plexiglass now, splitting the space you’re in into two, covering wall to wall, floor to ceiling.

This plexiglass ain’t your regular plexiglass my friend.

It’s been crafted especially for you by a team of world-class plexiglass masters, who’ve been passing their plexiglass crafting arts from generation to generation.

Actually … 

It’s even better than that.

It’s been crafted by something way more powerful: Your mind!

But seriously now, as you already see ${echo} now, I want you to also see yourself on the other side of it, over there, while you are right here, completely isolated from ${him}.

See yourself as you are today, wearing the same cloth, on the other side, beyond ${echo}.

answers.text: OK, I see myself on the other side

steps.title: Seeing yourself on the other side

answers.text: I’m done, and I’m holding the anchor

steps.title: Seeing yourself on the other side
steps.description:
Great, now watch yourself over there on the other side, playing with a cat in the same way, and having the same appropriate response. 

${his} immune system also knows exactly what to do now.

Keep holding the anchor as you do so.

answers.text: Watched ${him} playing with the cat, it was fun!

steps.title: Seeing yourself on the other side
steps.description:
${echo}

Great, now before we integrate these learnings you just witnessed on the other side, let’s do a quick check.

Since it’s your mind, might as well optimize and design your response as you see fit.

So, as you just witnessed yourself on the other side playing with a cat, is there anything in your response you’d like to change or optimize?

Either in your response on this side of the plexiglass, or the response of yourself on the other side.

(keep holding the anchor)

answers.text: There is something I want to change
Nothing to change, my response is good

steps.title: Making way for changes
steps.description:
*“There is something I want to change”*

Great observation!

There’s no rush, and it’s great that you want to optimize your mind and your life, and you are not settling.

I like that!

You can release the anchor now.

Now, here’s what we’ll do.

First, run your phone number, social security number, or ID number in your head.

answers.text: I’ve ran my social security number

steps.title: Making way for changes
steps.description:
${echo}

Great, now run it in your head again, this time backwards, from the end to the beginning.

We are doing this to do a quick “reset” in your mind, and make way to the changes you are about to install.

It’s not fun but it is useful, and we’ll get back at having fun shortly, promise!

answers.text: I’ve ran it backwards, ready for fun again!

steps.title: Going back for changes
Preparing for integration
steps.description:
*“Nothing to change, my response is good”*

Great, now keep holding the anchor, and as you do so, allow the plexiglass to disappear, so there’s nothing between you and yourself who just played with the cat with the good response.

answers.text: OK, plexiglass has disappeared, still holding the anchor

steps.title: Integrating learnings
steps.description:
Now bring ${him} into you, so you will learn everything ${he} already knows, including how to play with cats and have a good healthy response, as you keep holding the anchor.

Take as much time as you need to integrate these learnings.

When you feel you are ready, let’s continue.

answers.text: Integrated ${him} into me, ready to continue
I have learned everything ${he} learned, let’s continue

steps.title: Solidifying learnings (+ enjoyment?)
steps.description:
${echo}

Good.

Now, while still holding the anchor, imagine playing with a cat in the same way right here, in the same way you’ve just learned.

Touch it in the same way, feel it in the same way, so you have the same or better response.
steps.notes: (hint: you are not forbidden from enjoying this)

answers.text: Played with the cat, a good response
Played with the cat, an even better response!

steps.title: Furry gratitude
steps.description:
${echo}

Marvelous!

Now release anchor, and continue to play with the cat.

Pay extra attention how the cat enjoys your touch even more, deeply, and feel the cat’s gratitude and appreciation towards your touch and playfulness.

answers.text: The cat really enjoys it now

steps.title: Welcome
